Of course, for both (2) and (3), we prove that they are secure according to our DIDComm model.

Concerning implementation. In (2), our improved mode is not directly compatible with the JSON encryption standards, but these are easily extensible to incorporate it, so we think it is a very worthwhile improvement not only for DIDComm, but for the JSON encryption space at large.

For example, ra-anon would allow DIDComm users to receive SSI credentials without leaking to third parties that they are receiving these credentials! Sounds useful, eg, for anoncreds â€“ which, by the way, are issued by some of the in-production projects using DIDComm.
Re: (3). All DIDComm modes leak the recipient(s)â€™ identifier(s). We give a simple mode (ra-anon) that hides them. We also specify how to combine our new mode with the existing ones.

Re: (2). The combination of anoncrypt and authcrypt duplicates a lot of work. We give an improved mode that saves one bulk data encryption and prevents duplicate identifiers. The former may save up to a few ms, and the latter a few hundreds of bytes â€“ both, per DIDComm route hop.
No big deal, but better to keep it in mind. Excluding this easily fixable weakness, we prove that DIDCommâ€™s spec is secure according to our model.

Re: (1). In our model and proof, we note that the combined mode doesnâ€™t generally ensure that all recipients will receive the same message. This is fixable just by using AES-CBC+HMAC, which DIDComm supports off the shelf.
Also, DIDComm allows combining these modes, providing authenticated sender towards the recipient (but anonymous to third parties), and confidential messages.
DIDComm offers two main encryption modes: anoncrypt (anonymous sender, confidential message) and authcrypt (authenticated sender, confidential message).

Our results. We:

(1) Give a composable model of DIDCommâ€™s encryption, and prove the security of its specification. We identify a minor weakness fixable without changing the protocol.

(2) Propose a 2x improvement for one of its modes.

(3) Propose a new privacy enhanced mode.
However, up to now, DIDComm lacked formal analysis. For cryptographers (and, indirectly, for everybody) this is no good, as DIDComm could pose certain security issues exploitable by attackers.
